headline: A Scotsman's Shepherd Pie
description: This shepherd's pie is made with sharp Cheddar cheese, smoked paprika, stewed tomatoes, and lamb. Use smoked Cheddar, if you have it.

video.description: See a version of shepherd pie with spiced ground lamb, mashed potatoes, and sharp Cheddar cheese.
video.name: A Scotsman's Shepherd Pie

name: A Scotsman's Shepherd Pie
recipeIngredient: 1 pinch salt and ground black pepper to taste
1 (16 ounce) can stewed tomatoes with juice, chopped
1 cup Irish stout beer (such as Guinness®)

recipeInstructions.text: Stir potatoes, sour cream, cream cheese, 1 tablespoon butter, egg yolk, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon black pepper together in a bowl until smooth.

Heat olive oil in a cast iron skillet or nonstick pan over medium-high heat. Add ground lamb, reduce heat to medium, and cook, stirring frequently, until browned and crumbly, 4 to 5 minutes. Pour off excess grease and season lamb with salt and black pepper to taste.

Stir tomatoes with juice, onion, and carrot into ground lamb; simmer until vegetables are tender, 5 to 10 minutes. Add peas, reduce heat to low, and cook, stirring frequently, until peas are warmed, 2 to 3 minutes.
Heat beer in a saucepan over medium heat; add beef bouillon. Cook and stir beer mixture until bouillon is dissolved, about 5 minutes.

Heat remaining 1 tablespoon butter in a separate pan over medium-low heat until sizzling. Whisk flour into butter until thick and paste-like, about 1 minute. Stir beer mixture and Worcestershire sauce into flour mixture until gravy is smooth and thickened, 2 to 3 minutes. Stir gravy into lamb mixture and simmer until mixture is thickened, at least 5 minutes.
Set oven rack about 6 inches from the heat source and preheat the oven's broiler. Grease a 9x12-inch baking dish.
Pour lamb mixture into the prepared baking dish. Carefully spoon mashed potatoes over lamb mixture, covering like a crust. Sprinkle Cheddar cheese, parsley, and paprika over mashed potatoes.
Broil in the preheated oven until crust is browned and cheese is melted, 4 to 5 minutes. Cool for about 5 minutes before serving.

review.reviewBody: My daughter's fiance loves Shepherd's Pie...it is his favorite. He recently did a lot of "fixit" things for me and I thought I would make your recipe...the only thing I changed was that I used beef, because lamb was $11.00 per pound! I also used frozen mixed veggies (carrots, green beans, peas and corn) in place of the fresh carrot and peas. I made everything ahead of time and did not put the potatoes on top until I was ready to cook the casserole. I followed the recipe exactly and IT WAS FABULOUS! He raved about it all night as did my daughter and he has been telling everyone it was the absolute best Shepherd's pie he has ever had! Thank you so much for this yummy recipe...obviously a total hit!

I made this for a St. Patrick's Day dinner with a few friends. I pretty much followed the recipe. I made it with the traditional lamb. Everyone said it was the best Sheppard's Pie they have ever had. I served it with Guinness and Irish soda bread.

Excellent! I made it with ground beef. Also made the gravy/sauce in the meat/veggie mixture, and added liquid smoke and dijon mustard to the mix. But a wonderful taste profile. Thanks for the post, my friend. 10/10 will make again.
I added a lot more vegetables and did everything in one skillet except the mashed potatoes. Delicious!

I didn't expect there to be so many steps but I didn't mind it too much. My household is not a huge fan of lamb but I still tried it with the lamb anyways. Everything went well together but we still didn't enjoy the lamb. I'll try beef or bison next time.

Delish! Even with my tweaks. Here's what I did: Made recipe, omitting cream cheese & egg from potatoes. Doubled carrots & peas, but omitted tomatoes, cooking veggies in half of the stout with a generous T. of tomato paste. Substituted dried mint instead of parsley because it's tasty with lamb and peas. Followed suggestion of cooking in oven, then browning under broiler. Thanks for recipe! Will become a cold night staple at our house.

Excellent. I did use ground beef . Precooked carrots a bit. Also sautéed a leek and onions a bit before adding the beef. Omitted the cream cheese because I forgot to buy it. Used one whole egg. Made roux of margarine and flour, added beer and broth and stirred until thickened. Then added to beef and veggies (including peas). Riley loved it.
I didn't change a thing. It was delicious.
I made this tonight for dinner and it was a hit! I followed the recipe as written other than mixing everything together in the pan I cooked the lamb in. Definitely will be making this again!
Tasted great! Used lamb and sirloin. I added some garlic and used more guiness. I cooked the veggies down in the pan after I drained the meat.. Will definitely make again there was hardly any left!
Dish intensive, but very happy with the outcome. Added mushrooms but pretty much stuck with the recipe.

Amazing flavors! It’s even better a day later. I put the parsley on and then baked. Recommend putting the parsley on after baking. Delicious, hearty meal. This one is going in my rotation, replacing Gordon Ramsey’s recipe.
Excellent recipe!
It was great.added garlic and I put it in a pie crust. To make kids happy. But turned out great
The flavor was good and a nice change from beef, but I guess I didn't let it cook down enough. Mine turned out very soupy.

This is very different than the shepherds pie I grew up on but I loved it. One thing I would do different the next time I make it would use less Worcestershire sauce but that is a personal taste. I’m just not a fan. I also didn’t separate pans. Mixed all in the cast iron skillet and worked well.
Omg ! So good! The beer made the flavor so authentic!

Everyone enjoyed it! I used bison because that’s what was in the freezer. It was a little tangy and I’m not sure what gave it that flavor so I’ll be reviewing the recipe and maybe adjusting for less tang.
This was excellent. The only substitution was I used Fie Roasted diced tomatoes for just a little more pizzaz.

So yummy! We used lamb from my son's farm, so very fresh. The Guinness gravy didn't thicken as much as I would have liked and the pie ended up being soupier than preferred but the taste was amazing. Well worth all the effort. My son enjoyed it so much for his 40th birthday!

2nd time I’ve made this, but made following changes this time. Replace stewed tomatoes with diced tomatoes and 1c water. 1 c frozen peas and 1 c frozen corn (I used white), double up the carrot, 1 clove garlic minced, double the gravy amount and thickener. Leave the mashed potato mix as is - delicious. Also, I put mine in a 2 qt casserole dish (slightly smaller than called for, but nicer servings). Doing what I did made the most amazing Shepherds Pie that I’ve ever eaten. My wife is a chef at a catering company and it blew her away.

Delicious! This was a huge hit for my picky family...Yay! Though as time- consuming as it is to make, I will be making this again. I did add garlic powder, onion powder, and Nature's seasons to the BEEF (my meat of choice) mixture. I used a can of Veg-Al and frozen peas as well. I also added a can of cream of mushroom soup to the beef mixture before I added the roux. I baked the meat mixture at 350 for 25 minutes before adding the mashed potatoes. I had to use a TON of salt for the mashed potatoes, and I always add Montreal Steak Seasoning to my mashed potatoes. (If you have never tried it, you won't make them any other way...the flavor the steak seasoning gives, is hard to beat!). Thanks for the recipe...
simple and tasty

I have made this twice as a Friday night dinner at the VFW post. Each time I have sold out. 50 dishes. The difference I make to it is I serve in a 7" round aluminum pan and each serving is 12oz of meat filling and 7 ice cream scoopers of mashed taters! It flies out of the kitchen!

The flavor is terrific! I made the recipe as written except for using meatloaf mix instead of ground lamb. The final meat mixture was a bit too soupy. Next time I will use canned tomatoes without their juice. I will also try diced or crushed tomatoes instead of stewed to distribute more tomato throughout the meat mix.

Delicious shepherd's pie, But I agree that it's is a lot of work. I think you can consolidate steps to minimize the number of pans needed to make this. I used cut up left over leg of lamb roast & just skipped step 2, throwing the cooked meat in with the veggies which I sautéed first. It was a little tough to spread the thick potato mixture (I use Greek yogurt), but it did not matter. Very tasty!
This pie is amazing. I made it and when friends came over and saw the leftovers I almost lost my reserves, everyone went back in for seconds.
Fantastic! My husband loved it too.

LOVED it!!
This is my second time making it and it's a winner!?? 
I mistakenly bought Extra Stout this time so it's a little bitter but still a hit.
This is melt in your mouth watery goodness. So glad I made this. Everyone should try this recipe.
This came out delicious. I did change it up by making it vegetarian. Instead of lamb I used beyond meat and there is also a vegan beef bullion, and added 3 cloves of garlic..very tasty.

Let me try this review again! 5 stars aren’t enough for this recipe. I’ve had “cottage” pie all my life growing up my mom made it once a week or so in Georgia. I’ve had Shepard’s pie in local pubs and nothing compares to this. I ate half the pan and couldn’t stop eating the mashed potatoes while I was waiting to put them on the top. Excellent recipe I’ll be making in the future!

I followed the recipe exactly except that I added 3/4 can drained corn for extra texture. The recipe has a lot of steps but the finished dish makes it worth it. This is the 1st for making a beer roux & it adds extra zing to the flavor of the filling. I want to make this for guests at Easter. No photo because we started eating straight out of the oven. Yum!
Excellent. Whole family enjoyed this. Even the kids!
Perfect!
Phenomenal recipe! The only change I made was to go heavier on the carrots! This has easily made my ultimate top 5 favorite meals list!

This was a winner. I am a vegetarian, but I love Shepherd's Pie, and I love Scotland, so I had to give it a try. My substitution is that I used Beyond Beef instead of lamb. Everything else I did as is, although I probably used extra smoked paprika since I love the stuff so much. It was really good. My husband loved it too, and he is picky (especially when I'm serving him fake meat). I will make this one a lot, especially in the winter. I made it in August, which was probably not the greatest idea, but it was worth it.

This was my first time making a Shepherd Pie but this recipe is so good! I only had ground beef so, out of necessity I used that. I plan to make it again and using ground lamb. It’s a savory & satisfying comfort food.

Everyone who eats this LOVES it! I stay true to the recipe, except for substituting 1 t onion powder for the onion (my family hates the texture of onions). Some notes that may help others: 5 cups of mashed potatoes is about 2.5 lbs. potatoes. I have also made this ahead of time and refrigerated it, heated it at 325 for 15-20 minutes, and then broiled it for 5 minutes on low to get the crispy potato crust. Turns out great every time!
Delish

First time making it, so followed recipe exactly. So delicious. Next time I'll change the steps around. There wasn't enough liquid in the stewed tomatoes to tenderize the carrots to my liking. I'll probably add the beer/bouillon along with the stewed tomatoes (in step 3) and just thicken it at the end.

Mikey Likes It!!

My husband and I have traveled to the UK alot, I lived there as a teen. I made this recipe wondering if he would like it, especially since he's not fond of lamb...he LOVED it! I told him it was lamb after he ate it and he shrugged and said it didn't matter it was the best shepherds pie he'd ever eaten. 

Thank you for giving us this recipe!
love it wish I got the gravy a little thicker but still. made it with Innis and Gunn instead of guinnes. a Scottish beer for a Scottish pie

Great recipe! My partner, who is not a big fan of lamb even loved it. We made very small adjustments by using 2 small carrots instead of one and 3/4 cup of peas instead of 1/2 cup. We also used 2 tablespoons of flour for the roux and the consistency was perfect. We will definitely be making this again!

a big hit with my husband! He was also excited that there were several bottles of Guiness left as well! Didn't change anything other than making it all in one pan. I might use a small casserole dish next time just because I like it thicker.
The beer and the Worcestershire sauce makes this dish stand out from all the other shepherd's pies. Loved it, thank you so much for sharing!
The only thing I did nit have was Guinness Beer and I used beef instead of lamb. My family loved it !

This dish was a huge hit with my crew. After reading reviews I opted to add flour to the meat then added the additional ingredients and added the potatoes in the same cast iron skillet I used for making the meat mix.. We opted for deer meat because that is what was on hand. Next time around I’ll add a little more flour as it was still a little on the runny side and more meat. And maybe a little cayenne to give it some kick and a little more pepper. (We like spicy..). My son suggested putting it in a pie shell next time to add a bit of texture. All in all a fantastic recipe. The meat filling would definitely make a great pot pie filling. This will certainly be on the menu again.

Ok this was DELICIOUS! I doubled the filling recipe, used a 9x13 dish and just made enough potatoes to cover the top well (I actually had left over mashed potatoes which was why I decided to make this in the first place). It was SO SO GOOD. I used a lager and I liked the flavor but if you didn’t you could just replace it with beef broth.

I liked the idea of the "stout gravy" as well as the tomatoes to help make the filling moist. I did substitute mock mashed potatoes made from Cauliflower, hats off to George Stella for that recipe. Our low carb version of this recipe was a hit!
this is one the best "shepherds pie" spinoff recipes I've ever tried. made it dairy free and used venison for the meat. gravy was phenomenal!
Loved this recipe. The Guinness adds such flavor. Will definitely make this again

Wow! This was awesome! I had seconds and I'm not really a meat eater. Next time, I'll saute carrots and onion first. and maybe add mushrooms. I put half the cheese in the potatoes, but the crunchy brown cheese on top was perfect, so much sure you put enough on top, cause who doesn't like more cherse?

Shepherd's Pie is a favorite of our family. During the quarantine I didn't have my normal English seasoning blend so I found this recipe. It looks more complicated than it really is--actually quite easy. Couldn't find lamb so I had to use ground beef but it was still delicious. The potatoes are fantastic on their own so make a little extra for another night. We enjoyed it was yeast rolls , a salad and a rerun of Outlander.

Other than using a different beer, quarantine at the moment, I made it exactly as written as luckily I had everything else on hand. Flavor is different from other SP recipes, and I have made several, but really good. I will say, even after waiting for it to set it was still a little soupier than other recipes, the first night. HOWEVER, the next day this was perfect! This will become my new go-to SP recipe.

I lived in Great Britain for three years and have had lots of traditional Shepherd's Pie. This is the best recipe I have found and the combination of flavors is better than the originals. The entire family thought it was amazing...including my finicky pea-hating kids. I got around their pea-aversion by using a food processor to chop some semi-frozen peas into small pieces along with the carrots and onion. Since they were no longer pea-balls, they didn't even notice. I didn't have any Guiness on hand either, so substituted with a dark porter beer. It had the same effect and was amazing in the gravy.

This was really really good as written. An excellent recipe for experimenting with! I would have used half a beer rather than a whole beer, but that's just a personal preference. I used ground turkey and added more flour to the stew part to further thicken it. mushrooms and beef stew meat is also excellent. I highly recommend skin on red potatoes with garlic, cheese, sour cream, and butter, you won't regret it!

So yummy! I followed the recipe for the most part. I didn't have any beef bullion cubes, so instead I used a packet of beef gravy mix (I didn't add any of the flour that the recipe calls for). I also wanted creamier potatoes, I added cream to the consistency I like. I used Guinness beer ??. This recipe is absolutely delicious! The only thing I will change for next time is perhaps draining the stewed tomatoes. I feel like that made it a little too soupy. The flavor is amazing!

Wife made with a few minor modifications, but it was fantastic. We will definitely be making this again!

-Beef vs lamb.
-Gravy vs bullion cube.
-Baked it at 400 / 20 minutes vs broiling.

It turned out incredible! I only made a couple changes. I substituted diced tomatoes with jalapeños for the stewed tomatoes and used a additional 1/2 cup of cheddar. It had a lot of flavor with just a little kick. I’ll definitely make it again.

I loved this recipe! there was no lamb due to coronavirus bare shelves. So I used ground meat, 2.25 lbs. Added one more cup of Irish beer to the roux. 2 tbsp. of flour to thicken, and increased beef broth to two cubes. My potatos were made day before and cold. I mixed all into them including 1 egg yoke. Needed to add 1/3 cup milk to potatos to get them to fluff up. Next time, I will warm up potatos before mixing. The quantity of the beer sauce was spot on! I figured it right. Everyone asked for seconds, so it was a hit! Glad I made larger quantity of this recipe because we have delightful leftovers. After I assembled the dish, I did heat in oven on 350 degrees for 20 minutes because my taters hadnt been preheated.
First time we had lamb at the table. Certainly distinct! Recipe was sharp as-is. Great comfort food.
So many years lost, where has this been all my life?! It was wonderfully amazing!

Very tasty! The Guinness and the smoked paprika really added a lot to the richness. I substituted non-fat Greek yogurt for the sour cream, Neufchatel cheese for the cream cheese, and Beyond Beef plant-based "meat" for the lamb. My spouse and I are on the Noom program, so I'm constantly trying to revise recipes to make them a little less caloric and a little healthier. Next time I make this I'm going to try to substitute soy or almond milk for the sour cream and cream cheese. I'm sure there will be a noticeable difference, but I'm willing to give it a try. But it was great as is!

Sooo goodI have made this 3 times in 2 weeks! The stout beer gravy really makes this dish. I made 2 changes, instead of putting under the broiler I baked in oven at 350 for about 30 mins I used my own mashed potato recipe which contains sour cream anyway and I don"t put cheese on top, if you leave the cheese off, the potato forms a nice crust. This pie is so flavorfull you wont miss the cheese. I made it twice with ground lamb and once with angus ground beef )which technically makes it a cottage pie) it is really good both ways but I prefer it with the lamb. You can adjust seasonings to suit your tatse but don"t leave the beer out! This is the shepard's pie recipe I will use from now on, thanks for posting rhis wonderfull recipe.
Good, but not better than a much simpler recipe I make.
This was delicious. I made it for my daughter and her family and it was gone in one setting. Definitely will make it again. I added extra peas and carrots because I love veggies!
Loved it!!! Easy to follow. The only thing I added was onion and garlic salt to the mashed potatoes.

This recipe was amazing! I enjoyed Shepherds pie in the UK many times during the year i lived there and have always looked for the ultimate recipe. The Guinness was a great addition that added even more flavor to an already delicious recipe. I used ground beef rather than lamb, but it would be fantastic with either. I served this at a dinner with friends and they all asked for the recipe. I'll definitely make it again.
Added garlic and lowered the onion content a bit for the wife's tastes.
This recipe tastes so good! I am a novice cook and the instructions were easy to follow. Everyone thought I had been cooking this Shepherds Pie for years and it was the first time I ever made one.
My favorite Shepherd’s Pie recipe ever! This is my second time making it, and it’s even better this time.
yum, worth the work of mashing potatoes and making the gravy.

I must say, " I'm a believer!!! I am not a fan of this kind of dish but my husband and my son love it so I gave it a try. The two couldn't stop eating especially my son. The only thing I changed was, I didn't add tomatoes due to dietary restrictions and I didn't have Worcestershire and replaced with knorr savor seasoning but still amazingly delicious!!! My husband got to enjoy the leftover beer.
I’m not the best cook however this dish made it appear I am! It’s also delicious the next morning for breakfast with a fried egg on top.
Gourmet shepherd's pie - the best I have ever tasted. Somewhat work intensive but SO worth the outcome!
Very good. I'll make it again, but I'll add less potatoes next time. They seemed a little thick, but still it was delicious.
Delicious!! I will definitely make this again!
Delicious.
Really interesting recipe, very tasty.
Beeeeeautiful

I don't know how to edit my review. When I make it again, I'll use fewer potatoes -- more like a frosting than a layer. I'd leave it in the oven longer. I liked the crispy crust that forms along the edges. I'd add more veggies -- celery and green beans in addition to the peas and carrots. I'd reduce the amount of tomato product (I'm assuming here that we all use what we have -- sauce, diced, whole, etc.) I don't know what it would taste like with beer, but I'm not willing to experiment with it because the red wine was sooo delicious.
Excellent the way it is!
Delicious! My family ate all of it even though they proclaimed they weren’t hungry. I made h the potatoes 2 days in advance and let them warm up.
Delicious! My family ate all of it even though they proclaimed they weren’t hungry. I made h the potatoes 2 days in advance and let them warm up.

Overall, there were too many flavours vying with each other. Guinness just didn't seem right - made it a heavier dish than I'm used to, as did the cream cheese, though the sour cream gave it a nice tang. I've tried mash with sour cream since (though not the cream cheese and egg yolk) and it's good.
I won't make this again - paprika, Guinness, sour cream, Worcester sauce - just too much for a Scot like me!

Very good! The cream cheese and garlic powder was a great addition to the mashed potatoes. I thought it needed a little more ground meat... had no more lamb so added a little beef. GREAT flavor... will certainly make again!
I used ground turkey instead of lamb and my family loved it. Will be adding this to our regular meal rotation.
turned are really good! followed recipe except for the stout, I subbed fosters because that's what we had.

I'm going to give it 5 stars because I didn't follow the instructions exactly. Some traps I ran into were that the onions were not cooked well enough. I wonder if they should have been cooked with the lamb. I also used way too many pans. I will be thinking about how I can reduce that number.

Over all though it was delicious.
I like Shepard's pie, but it usually is just missing something to enhance the flavor. This Guinness gravy just made it AMAZING. I have passed this recipe around and it is now the only way we cook it.

This was the best Shepard's Pie I've ever made! So I used instant mashed potatoes but instead of milk I added sour cream like the recipe used for fresh mashed potatoes. Im sure the cream cheese could've been added too. I added more salt, personal preference maybe? And I also let the meat mixture cook longer then was said to make the tomatoes cook down. That's all. It's a awesome recipe and I will be making it again!

I’m not a lamb fan to say the least so was EXTREMELY nervous about using it on this dish but after reading all the reviews decided to experiment. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed the hearty meal! So much so that he actually had a second serving right away. Did recipe as instructed and will be saving it for future use! Thank you!
I substituted hamburger, as my husband does not like lamb. Took it to a potluck; everyone loved it and wanted the recipe. I will be making this again.

my family loved it. i made the mashed potatoes a little differently-- no egg yolk, a little milk--and just put the beer in the roue without heating with bullion. I put the bullion and the worchestershire directly into the pan with the lamb and veggies. I also used a large frying pan that can go in oven so just put mashed potatoes on top and under the broiler. 1 less pan to clean
Soooo yum,i do think that the process could be streamlined to save time however,see other reviews on that
This turned out great! Full of flavor! The stout gravy added so much to it and the cream cheese and sour cream in the potatoes made it so creamy and smooth. Will definitely make again!

To be fair, I do not care for lamb so my own taste is a bias up front. That said, my spouse very much liked this and had requested Shepherd's Pie for his birthday dinner. So, I will make this again but will use beef instead. I also will say, that we really liked the mashed potatoes that are made in this recipe so I will use those ingredients for our next side dish of mashed potatoes. Thanks for the recipe!
Had to exchange a few things, but followed the steps. It was delicious
